dialogues.speaker: SUPERSCRIPT
dialogues.text: A small country town. Normally quiet at this hour, the street is tonight alive with trick or treaters dressed as witches, goblins and superheroes making their annual door door rounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GLADYS PERRY, 30 going on 45 due to single motherhood and having worked two fulltime minimum wage jobs the past ten years, looks out the window with disgust and pulls the curtains closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gladys retreats   from the sparsly decorated living room predictably drab   linoleum kitchen. At the table, hands their laps, sit   her children, NAOMI and RUTH, twin girl 10, and PHILLIP,   a quiet boy of 8.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Gladys sets a casserole on the table and goes to the frig a container of milk. The children WHISPER to one another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judy Baumer is going as a twirler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's so fat.     I'd go as Cinderella... or Peter Pan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter Pan's a boy. Tinker Bell's a girl. Phillip could go as Peter Pan... 'cept you gotta' fly. Phillip smiles a bit at the notion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip could go as a bump on a log. The girls giggle and Phillip frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't we go just once?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caus' we jus' can't, ok? Gladys sets milk and butter on the table and stares direc at her son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our personal beliefs lift us to a higher place. 'Sides, Halloween is nothing but the Devil's work. The DOORBELL RINGS.   The kids gulp as Gladys turns and h for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. HUGHES, a 35-year-old family man is playing chaperone prepubescent versions of SUPERMAN, TINKERBELL, and a DANC SKELETON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in unison)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trick or treat!!! Gladys simply stares at the children before looking to Mr Hughes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry but we don't take no part in Halloween.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? Phillip arrives at his mother's apron. He stares at the k with relish. In the near window, Ruth and Naomi steal a l through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're Jehovah's Witness. Superman locks eyes with Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Phillip Perry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Billy Reeves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd ya' know it was me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go eat your supper, Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, kids. Let's go to the next house. Sorry for the bother. Gladys closes the door firmly and locks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A green Impala pulls up to the main entrance and stops. A GUARD steps from his office to greet the driver, LARRY, a pudgy 55-year-old prison employee wearing a loud plaid ja

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evenin', Larry.   Forget somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goin' to Austin tomorrow.      Gonna' take some work with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work, work, work. When you and me gonna' go out and grab a cold one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sooner the better. The gate opens and the Impala passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BUTCH HAYNES, a 38-year-old inmate who reeks with knowled procured from the wrong side of the tracks, but whose sad tired eyes bemoan a maximum of regret, stands on the top cell bunk chipping at the ceiling. JERRY PUGH, 29, rail thin, a punk who constantly licks hi lips, keeps watch at the door. An OLD TIMER sits on his b and watches both with a cautious eye. Butch chips through to something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn if the old man ain't right. Jerry smiles, turns and grabs the old man by the shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this goes to the roof?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used to... afore they walled it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it don't I'm gonna' rip your tongue out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get yer' damn hands off me! Jerry laughs and joins Butch, who is already well on his to bending open a slot in a corrugated metal air shaft hi behind the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Superman and Dancing Skeleton, no longer with adult super vision, fill water balloons at an outdoor water spigot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make 'em small so you can heave 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An assembly line at the kitchen sink as the twins wash an Phillip dries the evening dishes. Gladys sits at the kitc table, reading religious pamphlets and keeping a watchful over the process. Several THUDS resound through the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in the world? Phillip jumps down off his stool and races into the livin room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Superman lofts a BALLOON and grabs another as the first h the door of the Perry house and SPLATTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bombs away! Dancing Skeleton does his best Warren Spahn and tosses a fastball at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your trick! At the window, Phillip, his nose pressed to the pane, sta expressionless at the onslaught. He barely flinches as a BALLOON SPLATS only inches away. Gladys arrives and pulls the curtains shut once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch kicks the top off a ventilator shaft and rolls onto roof. Jerry follows as Butch shimmies to the wall. At the edge, Butch and Jerry survey the yard as a searchl routinely bathes the walls in a circle of light.

dialogues.speaker: GREEN IMPALA
dialogues.text: parked almost directly below them, next to the Administra office of the prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'n'me must be livin' right, Butchie boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get something straight. I don't like you. As soon as we're on our way, that's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said I liked you? Butch slides down and hangs from the ledge before droppin the roof of the building below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SOFT THUD causes a Guard to look up, but only momentari he spots Larry departing, files in hand, waving goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a safe trip now, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as Larry reaches the Impala, Butch and Jerry leap do and land on him. The spotlight showers them in a flash of light as it passes by. Butch cups his hand over Larry's mouth while Jerry reache into his jacket -- Bingo -- a shiny .38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Larry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep yer' mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Larry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gawd I'd love to blow yer' head off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry, driving with his eyes straight ahead, stops at the and waves a palm at the Guard, who opens without hesitati

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Night, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: stuffed and hidden half on the floor and half under the m are Jerry and Butch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Night, Larry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A weathered finger drops a quarter in a jukebox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: B-5.   Haven't heard that one in awhile. The woman, MAE, 45, a dog-tired waitress, punches in the numbers and returns to her post behind the counter. A lonesome HANK WILLIAMS tune pours forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not since last night.     How's the pie? RED GARNETT, 60, a grizzled but handsome Texas Ranger, si at the counter slowly chewing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinda rubbery.   It was better yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same pie as yesterday. Not much call for rhubarb. Sell one slice a day. In the background we hear a SIREN. Red turns and watches police patrol car whiz past, lights on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yer off duty. Tell me, if I stopped bakin' 'em would you still come by every night? Red, preoccupied, takes another rubbery bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Mae smiles and turns her back to Red as she cleans the gr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, Red Garnett, you don't come in here for the coffee and pie. You come in here for the company. To see me. Another patrol car races past.   Red's eyes follow it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that I've said that, I'll go   one better. What say I cook you dinner at my   place sometime? Steaks, baked taters,    cold beer, the works. Well?... I'm askin'    you out. She turns to face Red but he's gone. A coupla dollars lie next to the half-eaten pie. All she can do is sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red pulls up in front of a small house in a residential section of town. Police cars are everywhere and several officers are behind their vehicles, guns pointed at the h Red steps out of the car and is greeted by a POLICE SERGE about the same age as Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long time, no see. What are you doin' here, Chief?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't sleep.   Whattaya got?

dialogues.speaker: 16C CONTINUED
dialogues.text: They walk. Red arrives at a truck with a 10 gallon coffee urn roped to the tailgate. He grabs a paper cup and pours

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy holdin' his family hostage. She kicked him out, served him divorce papers, he came back drunk and pulled a .38. Fired two shots but we don't think anybody's hit. Actually you might know the guy from your sheriff days. Hayden Webb. Been on suspension for awhile. Ring any bells?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Lemme talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No can do.   Police jurisdiction. Red tastes the coffee -- cold. He spits it out, pours the contents of the cup on the ground and walks toward the fr yard. Sergeant follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how are you guys doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got specific rules to follow in these kinda situations, Red. (gives in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He won't talk. Jus' keeps yellin', crying and waving his gun around. Red moves forward into the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least use the megaphone, you stubborn jackass! But Red ignores and arrives at the front door.   He knock

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayden, this is Red Garnett. We worked together a few years back. Mind if I come in? The YELLING inside STOPS and the door opens a crack.   HA 35, distraught, peers out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Evenin', Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it to the P.D. They got a three- ring circus out there and not one cup of hot coffee. You mind? Hayden mulls it over, then opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the couch sits Hayden's wife, JULIE, cradling her two an infant and an 8-year-old boy. Julie sobs. Her eye and temple are bruised purple. Red slowly enters, nods to Julie, takes off his hat and s it on a lampstand. Hayden has moved away from Red against the wall. He holds the gun out at no one in particular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie, put a pot of coffee on. She slowly gets up and moves to the kitchen, still weepin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Appreciate it.   Jus' what is it you want, Hayden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno... I want my job.    I want my family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd they suspend you for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I answer a call in South Austin. Girl gettin' raped, that's the word. I bust in the door, this lowlife is beatin' the shit outta her with a tire iron. 'Help me, help me,' she says. I take the guy down. He bites me. I break his arm. Case closed, right? No. She was his wife and they both sue me and the department. The guy's about to kill her and she sues me 'cause now he can't pump gas. They have chump change in the bank but they got the best lawyer in town. Three months I'm goin' crazy. No pay. Then my wife leaves me and I get served divorce papers by John Reese -- a sheriff's man. You know how embarrassin' that is? What's happenin', Chief? I mean, everybody's got a fuckin' lawyer! Julie emerges from the kitchen and retakes her seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You love her?    Love the kids?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why do you hit me! Hayden grips the quivering revolver tight and points it at her. Red calms the situation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't wanna shoot her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to God I think I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, Hayden, I don't     think so. I think you love her. You know      what else I think? That you'd like a way out     of this whole mess... That's where I come     in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant and other cops stand around and watch the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll be damned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door opens and Julie emerges with her two kids. She takes a few cautious steps, then runs to the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red sits on the coffee table, unloading Hayden's gun. opens the cylinder and drops the shells to the floor. A calmer Hayden exits the kitchen with Red's coffee. accepts it, takes a sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hits the spot. Hayden starts to sob a bit.      Red hands over a handker which Hayden accepts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No cuffs, huh, Chief?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   You ready? Hayden nods, they stand. Red picks up his hat, sticks it on his head, opens the door and holds it for... Hayden, transfixed by the multitude of lights outside. gulps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll walk out together, okay? Hayden steps back, looks at Red, then reaches behind his back, underneath his shirt and pulls out a .22 pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any good officer has a back-up. Red holds his palms out and takes a step toward Hayden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme have it, Hayden. Hayden points the gun at Red, freezing him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was I a good officer, Chief? Red nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was I a good deputy? The kinda man you could depend on to do what's right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Hayden smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Then he turns the GUN on himself, swallows the barrel and BLOWS his brains out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayden's dead, covered body is carried out the door.    J screams and sobs, still holding her crying children. Red, looking pretty shook up, slowly exits the house. He stops and looks at Julie and the kids. His eyes lock with the little boy's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a call, Chief Garnett.   They're lookin' for ya downtown. Red slowly walks away.   The little boy's eyes follow him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a small town version of a 7-11, kept open by an owne anxious to cash in on the later night munchies of beer drinkers. Good idea. Bad luck.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jerry skims through a girly magazine, turning the pages w the gun. Butch, wearing Larry's plaid jacket, jimmies open the cas register. He looks to the floor then to... Jerry, who catches Butch's gaze, holds it, looks down at floor, then, smiling, looks back to Butch. He returns to the skin mag. Butch holds his stare at Jerry then, in one move, grabs a of cash and hops over the counter and out of the store. Jerry notices Butch leaving, grabs a handful of assorted Brach's candies and hurries after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, wait up! Jerry's feet scurry through a pool of blood and past a quivering hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very late, after midnight, and only a handful of peo half of whom are cleanup crews, shuffle through the offic A light from an office at the end of the hall catches our eye. A MUFFLED  VOICE over the phone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understan' your concern, Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red, behind a huge    ranchstyle desk covered with files paper, sips coffee    with one hand, works a buffalo nick through magician's    paces with the other and balances t phone receiver in    the crook of his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cons are creatures o' habit. Like old coyotes, they'll crawl back into familiar holes. Uh huh... Yeah... Sure yer' right. Listen you go back to bed and I'll call you in the A.M. with an update. I'll have the files by then. Say hullo to the Mrs.. Red sighs, puts the PHONE back in the hook and stares at it until it RINGS again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CLANGING wind up alarm CLOCK reads 5:30 and Gladys op her eyes and gently quiets it with a touch. She groans an rises, not happy but used to the daily ritual required of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the kitchen light comes on we see that the couch has b opened up to a bed in which all three children sleep. The twins sleep soundly but Phillip tosses and turns away fro the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Impala creeps through the previously seen neighborhoo without its lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch drives while Jerry scours the block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a Buick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't want a Buick. Want a Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ford's leak oil.     A car's a car. Butch puts on the brakes and brings the car to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then take the Buick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon as we cross state line I'll do just that. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired of riding around. I'll check down the block... for a Ford! Jerry gets out, slams the door, lights a cigarette and wa away. Butch waits a few seconds, quietly turns the key one notc and checks the gas ggauge. It reads almost empty. He taps it with his finger but it doesn't budge. He sighs, looks and sees...

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: as he checks one locked car, then feeling eyes on his bac turns, looks at Butch, grins and disappears around a corn BUTCH discreetly exits the car himself, carefully closing door without a sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gladys steps into a slip and snaps her bra while cracking into a skillet. By rote she salts, stirs, and pops bread the toaster.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: FROM BEHIND a fence, THROUGH the opened, screened windows see Gladys at work. Phillip enters, dressed in cotton briefs and a T-shirt, d a chair from the kitchen table by the window and assists mother by buttering the toast. POV MOVES CLOSER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Phillip. Go wake up your sisters. Phillip dutifully steps down and returns to the living ro Gladys works to adjust her slip, then grabs plates and silverware and takes them to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take mine fried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gladys gasps at Jerry's face pressed against the screen, controls herself when he brandishes the pistol. He motion for her to open the back door. She does. He slides into t room and sits down at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Ford sits in a driveway. In the far b.g. a back porch l glares. Butch ENTERS FRAME, looks at the light, turns to Ford and starts to jimmie the lock. No luck. He rises and looks to the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry stuffs a piece of toast in his mouth, grins at Glad and makes a motion to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lil' on the bland side.   Gimme' that ketchup. She picks up a bottle of Heinz and inches toward him. Whe she gets close, he grabs her and forces her onto his lap. holds the gun to her throat and whispers in her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't got a man around here, do ya'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MR. CUMMINGS, 70, puts on his glasses and peers through t window.

dialogues.speaker: PERRY KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Gladys sits on Jerry's lap, thanks to .38 caliber coercio The convict's hands move freely over the frightened woman body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feed me, sweet thing. Her shaking hands raise a forkful of eggs to his lips. licks them once then gobbles with gusto. Phillip enters the room and stops dead in his tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well lookie here, you do got a man! Jerry smiles at Phillip while he kisses and licks Glady's At once, Phillip darts across the room at Jerry, who back the boy with his gunhand, sending Phillip sprawling. Butch blasts through the door in an instant. With a swift kick to the head, Jerry is knocked senseless onto the flo against the cabinets. The gun slides across the floor and lands at Phillip's fe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding his ear)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm bleedin'! You happy? Butch gives Jerry an icy stare and kneels down to eye lev with Phillip. Butch looks at the gun and then at Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared shitless)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ph...   Phillip...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, okay Phillip. Reach down and pick up that pistola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jerry)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut yer' mouth. (to Phillip)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pick it up and bring it over here.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Phillip reaches down and slowly picks up the gun by the h He takes one step toward Butch, then another. Gladys, petrified, sobs. Phillip arrives armslength from Butch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now say 'stick 'em up.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stick 'em up... Butch laughs and then a NOISE from outside brings him bac to reality. He grabs the gun and spins to see...

dialogues.speaker: MR. CUMMINGS
dialogues.text: Standing outside the screen door, gun leveled. Before the man can utter a syllable, Butch grabs Phillip and points gun straight at Cummings. Jerry jumps up and grabs Gladys

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the gun down, old timer. You couldn't hit me anyway. Probably shoot the boy. The PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it be. The twins wiping sleep from their eyes, wander into the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, honey. PHONE continues to RING. Cummings can't decide what to do with the gun he's pointing at Butch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You deaf?!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set it on the ground. Cummings reluctantly obeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta' get the hell outta'here!

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PHONE still RINGS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! In one fluid move he rips the phone from the wall.    The silence is deafening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: Gladys)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I vote we bring her with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How we gonna' get outta' here without a hostage, tell me that? The whole goddam neighborhood's awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take the boy. Silence.   Gladys can't believe her ears.   Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nooooo!!! Jerry tosses Gladys aside. She collapses onto the floor. The TWINS instantly start to CRY. Phillip winds up and hits Butch as hard as he can. Butch him up, directs Cummings into the kitchen with the gun an for Jerry to lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get him back. I swear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch, carrying Phillip, and Jerry emerge from the back o the house and race back to the Impala.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip!!!!... Butch flips Jerry the gun, tosses Phillip into the passen seat, leaps over the hood and into the driver's seat. The CAR STARTS and SQUEALS away. Neighbors, aroused by the noise, exit their homes clad in robes, nighties and curlers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry FIRES a SHOT over their heads, sending them to the or scurrying for safety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't you folks ever heard of sleepin' in?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cummings races from behind the house with the SHOTGUN, levels it and FIRES a BLAST... A nearby station wagon WINDOW SHATTERS. Rising from their cover position, its owners look at Cummings with disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice shootin', Fred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Garnett, still in the same clothes, rests the phone recei in his ear while he shuffles through the files before him Red's deputy and boy friday, TOM ADLER, 40, lank, thinnin hair, with a face as soft as Red's is hard, warms up Red' coffee with a jolt from the Chief's favorite plaid Thermo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Johnny, I do understand that... The jabbering on the other end of the phone line continue as Red's eyes squint to read the files.

dialogues.speaker: FILES
dialogues.text: The first is Jerry's, complete with a grinning mug shot i upper right hand corner. There are several pages in the f but Red's fingers quickly peruse the top rap sheet before turning to...

dialogues.speaker: SECOND FILE
dialogues.text: It's Butch's and again Red's fingers start to move down t page then they stop and move to the photo of Butch at the of the page.

dialogues.speaker: RED'S FACE
dialogues.text: A hint of recognition.    The jabbering continues...

dialogues.speaker: PHOTO OF BUTCH
dialogues.text: A little younger than now.    A younger con with the grim of a man facing hard time.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: keeps staring at the photo, oblivious to the phone conver tion he's "not having".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red?     Red, you there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Adler)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's talkin' to ya'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you heard a word I've said?! Red comes to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Johnny. Jus' thinkin' is all....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (another whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Press has been waiting almost an hour, Red. Red nods then notices someone at the door and motions her in... SALLY GERBER, 28, cute in a plain, no nonsense way, with giant curls accenting her round face in step with th latest hair fashions, enters the room, closes the door be her. She's nervous as hell but trying to hide it. Red motions her to have a seat while he finishes his call

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.... Clear as a bell... Mi' sabe. Red hangs up the phone, takes a draw on the coffee mug an looks again at the file. He seems lost in time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guvner', Red. Red closes the file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reminded me it's an election year. Red turns his attention to Sally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You drink before noon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.     Last one I had was on a liquid diet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (remembering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Penny Munroe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you have me confused. I'm here from Huntsville. Assigned by Governor Connally. Red is confused.     He turns a blank expression to Adler

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adler...    what is this? Adler searches the messy desk for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rings a bell, Red. Believ' they sent us something about her this mornin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who sent?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Guvner', Red. Adler finds the telex message sheet he's looking for and it to Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Here it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (introducing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, I'm Sally Gerber. Criminologist with the State Prison System. Sally offers her hand. Red, perusing the telex, ignores b Adler shakes somewhat reluctantly, not sure if he's suppo to like her or not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Adler.   Deputy. State Police... System.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a relatively new procedure but I was assigned by Governor Connally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from telex)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... 'to work with State law enforcement officials in all affairs where penal matters coincide with those of the State Police.' It don't say nuthin' about...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It includes parole and work release programs as well as penal escape situations. The office PHONE BUZZES.    Adler picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On our way, Marge. Adler hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gettin' antsy, Red. You scheduled it. Adler hangs up, grabs Red's tie and coat from a brass run the wall and hands them over. Red puts down the telex, st at Sally and reluctantly attempts to make himself present

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The idea is that an understanding of the particular behavioral case histories should, in parole situations, help the subject to avoid habitual traps and, in penal escape situations could, conversely, identify those self-same traps as an aide to apprehension.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Adler stares at Sally then turns to Red with a "never hea the like" look of amazement on his face. Red, roguishly handsome in his tan, western cut blazer, c on tie and ten gallon hat, makes his way to the door. But before he exits...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the first place, Miss Gerber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the first place, Sally, it ain't a 'penal escape situation.' It's a manhunt. Fancy words in a circle don't help much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what does?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nose like a Blue Tick, a medulla with an antenna and one helluva lot of coffee. And with that he's out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A throng of photogs and news writers stuff the undersized room. The clamor settles when Red enters and steps behind the lectern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen up, I'll only say it once. At approximately ten o'clock last night two inmates over to Huntsville, Robert 'Butch' Haynes and Jerry David Pugh, escaped through an air shaft, grabbed a prison employee's car and got out through the main gate. At approximately 1 A.M. we believe they robbed a market outside of Cut-n-Shoot and killed the store's owner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the prison employee with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was when they left the prison. Sally and Adler enter the room and stand beside the lecte observing. Red notices them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the rap sheet on these guys like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long as Christmas eve to a kid. Haynes was doin' 40 for armed robbery and Pugh was ridin' 20 hisself for manslaughter and assorted parole vios.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any indication of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Lemme' finish, Billy. This mornin' another hostage was taken... from a private home in Madisonville. A boy, age 8. Grabbed him out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any sex offenses on Haynes or Pugh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yer' askin' if they're preverts.   Well, one is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got inter-agency cooperation on this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Texas Rangers as the criminal investigation arm of the D.P.S. share responsibility with the F.B.I. due to the kid being taken. But I doubt they're out of bed yet. A few chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red, how do you plan to apprehend the escapees?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officially I can only say we have a full manhunt team on their trail and we'll proceed with due haste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And unofficially? Red hesitates a moment, something's bothering him, then b out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unoffically? I'm gonna' hunt 'em like the rabid dogs they are.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Every hand in the place shoots up and Ad Lib questions fl like bullets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all I've got but I'd like to introduce ya' to Miss Sally Gerber. She's straight from the Governor's office. Knows all about psychological profiles and the like. You probably have some questions for her. Red steps back and to one side. Sally is taken aback but warms to the idea and steps to the podium for her first p conference, ready to take on the tough questions, to show a bit, but.... There are no questions. In fact there is utter silence as every raised hand drops. Eyes stare. Red sighs and starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, fellas, I got work to do. And he heads out the door, followed by Sally's eyes and e reporter's in the room, who commence once again to yell o questions and mob after the Chief. Every reporter, that i except one. He's near the back of the room and he smiles and raises h hand. Sally, unsure what to do, looks to him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do. Sally smiles a bit then puts on her serious face awaiting

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You doin' anything tonight? Sally, steamed, glares at the guy and stomps out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch is driving with Phillip in the front seat beside hi still in his underwear. Jerry, in the backseat, leers at Butch, aims out the window and FIRES ONCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An aluminum water tank spews a violent leak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a handful of caps and yer' shootin' water tanks. He's a smart guy, huh, Phillip? Phillip doesn't move or change expression. Jerry smiles, almost to himself, and FIRES TWICE more for the hell of i The ROOF of the Impala EXPLODES with two holes as the car speeds off down the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red is finishing up with several reporters near the door the parking lot. Adler jumps in, holds up his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, that's it, boys.   Chief's got work to do. Red and Adler move through the parking lot to SAUNDERS, 5 aide to the Governor. Saunder's seconds are a PHOTOGRAPHE young and energetic, and SUTTLE, 35, dark-haired, with a cowlick. Saunders shakes Red's hand and they turn to gaze upon...

dialogues.speaker: '60-STYLE AIRSTREAM MOBILE HOME
dialogues.text: parked in the middle of the lot hitched to the back of a Chevy truck. The Airstream is painted in state colors and sports banners, decals and logos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Saunders follows Red as he walks around the showpiece, occasionally kicking a tire or two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So whattaya' think? Saunders motions for the Photographer to come closer and pictures. He moves in next to Red and poses as the camera clicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are very proud of this baby. Governor Connally special ordered it so state officials and dignitaries can ride in the parade in Dallas. You know President Kennedy's comin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latest technology, oversized engine, complete kitchen and sleeping quarters, gun racks, frig, stove, the works. Even got a hot line phone straight to the Governor's office. Red stops circling and nods to Adler, who scurries away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine piece of machinery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's more, as soon as it gets back from Dallas it will be at your requisitioned disposal. Perfect for lots of situations -- a headquarters on wheels. Red smiles, walks up to one of the Lone Star decals and r it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Chief?.... Red rips off another decal. Adler and a few others start load equipment, guns and files into the motor home. In addition they cart out unecessary items: mattresses, etc. and stack them in a pile outside the motor home. The Photographer continues to snap photos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Red)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whattaya' doin', Red?! (to Photographer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop takin' pictures! Red does away with the parade banner.   Saunders follows and tries to reinstate the decal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's jus' not possible, Red. The Governor's gonna' ride it in a campaign parade tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guvner' hisself told me this manhunt was top priority.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Adler moves through the door to the RV carrying Red's fav desk chair. He's followed by BOBBY LEE, 20's, cocksure, wearing a plain khaki uniform and boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Saunders)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S'cuse me. (to Red)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This here's Bobby Lee. He's a specialist with the Feds. They want him to tag along. Red stares hard at Bobby Lee, then nods.   Bobby Lee step into the Airstream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Red, ya' gotta' believe me... Red spots Suttle, 35, bright-eyed, with a cowlick, sittin the wheel of the Chevy truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick Suttle, the driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not anymore.   Bradley. BRADLEY, 35, glasses, moves to the truck and gets in. Suttle shrugs and steps out. Saunders stops Suttle and turns to Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man stays with the vehicle wherever it goes, Red!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Suttle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how to operate the gadgets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Suttle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grab a seat. Suttle sets himself in the passenger seat of the truck. Sally emerges from the building, ticked off, carrying an armload of file boxes, and makes a beeline for Red. Saunders gently touches Red's shoulders; a final plea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please Red, I'm beggin'. I mean, what am I suppose to tell the Governor? Sally arrives but before she can spit out a word...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell John that Miss Gerber here checked me out on it. Red whistles and the ENGINE REVS. Red closes the door as motor home pulls away. Saunders runs beside the passenger side window and yells in to Suttle, who stares out the wi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a scratch, you hear me, Suttle? Not a scratch! Saunders stops, breathing hard, next to Sally.   She's pissed and overloaded with files.

dialogues.speaker: AIRSTREAM
dialogues.text: about 20 yards down the way, comes to a stop.    A second the door opens and the steps pop out. Sally walks toward the bus but when she arrives at the do ... LAUGHTER filters out of the Airstream.   The Airstrea moves another 20 feet then stops. Sally waits a full five seconds, then she blows the hair of her eyes and, against her better judgment, moves cauti forward, the file boxes getting heavier by the minute. Ag when she gets close... ...the Airstream moves. Sally, boiling mad as her coiffur wilts in the Texas sun, stops, and tosses down the file b in anger. The Airstream stops. LAUGHTER from inside and a   few AD i.e. -- "Okay, Okay." More LAUGHTER. Red steps    out the turns his gaze back inside and the laughter and  comments on a dime. Smiling slightly he turns to Sally,   moves st for the file box, picks it up and walks back to  the Airs When he arrives at the steps he turns, looks to  Sally, w stews and holds her ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You comin' or not? She hesitates only a moment before walking straight to Re grabbing back her file box and entering in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally enters, balancing the   boxes, and glares at the fa surrounding her. A smiling    Red, a grinning Adler messi gorging on a cinnamon roll,   a nervous KAISER, the radio and, in the corner, a nasty   smirk from Bobby Lee. When the Airstream takes off again, she loses her balance drops one of the boxes. Adler and Suttle jump forward to but she gives them the evil eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got it. She kneels down to pick it up and feels eyes on her. looks up to the men staring at... Her skirt, raised a bit, exposing a thigh. She calmly stands and looks to Adler, a piece of cinnamon dangling on his chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got shit on your face. Red can't help but smile as Adler wipes at his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The IMPALA BLASTS along, kicking up dust and dispersing c as it heads into a one light township. It slows, however, before the main part of town and slides to a stop near a phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the hell we stoppin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you had a cousin near here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So give him a call. See if we can shack there til' things cool down. Jerry thinks it over, leans forward and, in one quick swi grabs the keys from the ignition. Then he laughs and craw out on his way to the phone booth.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: In the b.g. we see Jerry strut to the phone booth and por through a thin directory. Phillip steals a glance at Butc who watches his rear view mirror and grits his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd he take the keys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I won't leave him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a tad hopeful)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you leave him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. In the b.g. Jerry rips the 20 page phone book in half and returns to the car, half pleased with himself. He tosses the keys to Butch, who starts the car and drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Musta' moved. Prolly' couldn't have heard 'em anyway. Goddam ear's still bleedin'. You ever try that shit again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were in the middle of threatenin' me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the movies)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't a threat. It's a fact. Butch reaches over, takes Phillip's hand and places it on steering wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here kid, take the wheel. Phillip, scared at the prospect, nevertheless does his be to see over the dash and keep the wheel straight. Butch turns back over the seat to confront Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In two seconds I'm gonna' break your nose. That's a threat...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Before Jerry has time to snicker Butch hits him full in t face and grabs the gun. Blood spurts from Jerry's nose an the injured man cups his hands over the wound. Butch spins and retakes the wheel from a frightened Phill

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And that's a fact. Instead of expressing outrage, Jerry slinks back down in seat wearing a look of pure hatred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna' kill you for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's a threat. Beginnin' to understand the difference? Somethin' catches Butch's eye and he turns and slows down turns into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Impala brakes to a dusty stop near the front of the s which is bordered by a giant hay field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Phillip, listen up. I'm gonna' run in here and get some smokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get beer. Butch hands Phillip the revolver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, hold it like this.... And point it right between his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Phillip)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he so much as moves you pull the trigger ... right here... Put your finger on it. Jerry snickers and then laughs maniacally. Butch reaches over and cocks the pistol. Jerry's guffaws stop on a dime

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yer' a fuckin' crazy man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's a fact. I believe yer gettin' the hang of this. Butch steps out of the car and heads for the market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch enters.   A short fat man with a fishing cap is swe up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How-do.    Where's yer' sodees?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hot in the first aisle.       Cold in the back, in the cooler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip's slightly shaking hands hold the pistol pointed directly at Jerry's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever shot a gun before, boy? No answer. Phillip steals a glance at the store, anxious Butch to return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Powww!!!...    It'll knock you on your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be quiet, mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw. You ain't never shot no gun before. Livin' in a house with three split tails... no Daddy around. You'll prolly' grow up queer, you know that? A bead of sweat rolls down Phillip's cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm gonna' lean up here real slow, okay? So we can talk. Jerry raises his hands, palms up and slowly leans forward the back seat. Phillip's hand quivers but he doesn't pull the trigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There we go. Now we can have a 'man to man.' You are a man, ain't ya'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch dumps a six pack of RC Colas, a handful of Moon Pie a handful of beef jerky and some gum on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry's chin is on the front seat now and his arms are dr over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are cute little underwears you got there, boy. Say does your mama sew yer' name in 'em, initials or anything? Jerry's hand slowly reaches down to the white briefs. He places one finger in the front elastic waistband and slow pulls it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha' got in there? Jerry sneaks a peek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinda' puny, ain't it? Phillip, diverted, looks down.    In a flash Jerry grabs gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hand is quicker than the eye. Jerry flicks open the revolver, spins it -- empty slots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: Butch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sonofabitch. Hell's bells, no shells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Old Man puts down his broom and ambles to the registe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This be all for ya'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This and a carton of Chesterfields. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are those .38 shells? Gimme a box. The Old Man puts the cigs and shells on the counter and s to tally the bill on a notepad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With deposit comes to four dollars eighty. Butch reaches in his pocket and extracts the wad stolen f the convenience store. The Old Man takes note. Butch selects a five and places it on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Land's sake.   What line of work you in? The Old Man bags the goods, but Butch takes the shells an puts them in his coat pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Used cars. Buy 'em, fix 'em up. Sold a Cadillac down in Madisonville this mornin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry puts his gun hand around Phillip's neck and pulls t sobbing boy closer. Jerry rests his face on Phillip's nec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come over a little closer. As Jerry    groans, Phillip seizes the moment and bites J hard on    the ear. Jerry screams and drops the gun, whic Phillip    picks up and carries with him as he scurries o the car    and into the hay field. Jerry, in pain, now with both ears bleeding, crawls out o the back seat and gives chase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip, still sobbing, runs for his life in the hay, whi is a full foot taller than he.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: no longer stumbling, now grinning maniacally, gives chase whistling as if calling for a lost puppy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna' find you boy.    You best come here.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: gun in hand, stumbles, falls, gets up, keeps running. He again and crawls to a stop. He wipes his tears and balls on the ground trying to make himself invisible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch exits with a grocery sack. When he sees the car doo open he dumps the groceries in the front seat and looks t the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hay rustles as Jerry moves through the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry, crouching, moves through the field -- eyes peeled any sign of Phillip. Phillip lies still. He hears the hay rustling near him an he looks up, squares his body and points the revolver at. Butch, who spots him, motions for him to stay put and hol out his hand for the gun. Phillip hands it over and watch while Butch reaches into the plaid jacket pocket, extract few shells and loads the .38.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: a little frustrated now, but still moving forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey boy. Hey boy. You better hope I don't find ya'. He spots something -- a dash of color -- and begins to cr faster. He parts a thick batch of hay and looks up into t gun barrel and eyes of ...

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: squatted down,   who levels the revolver and closes one e Jerry laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha' gonna' do? Hit me with it? Butch reaches into the coat pocket with his free hand and shows a shell or two. Jerry's grin drops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pleading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me'n you are friends!!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thick as theives.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: hears a GUNSHOT and runs for his life back toward the sto

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip runs to the car and hides behind the tire opposit store and field. In the b.g. we see Butch emerge from the field and walk toward the car. The Old Man, who also heard the shot, emerges from the st with a baseball bat.   Butch arrives at the car, spots th Man and levels the revolver at him. Phillip is relieved w he hears Butch's voice instead of Jerry's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Old Man)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then go inside and lie down til' we're gone. The Old Man meekly does so. Butch goes to the car door, o it and motions to a frozen stiff Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... Get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck and Airstream barrel down the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is a functioning mobile headquarters now. Adler the short wave and tacking up a map, Bobby Lee still in h corner, Red and Sally sitting across from one another at "kitchen table". In the rear section of the Airstream Red's chair and a mi office for the Chief have been put together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a spot on 'em. A store right outside of Benhur. About 20 miles from here. Adler sets down the mike, sticks a tack on the map and st back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Push the roadblock on 288 north by 50 miles. Kaiser calls in the instructions. (NOTE:   Kaiser's radio transmissions are not scripted but go on a lot of the tim we're in the Airstream. In addition, his  and Adler's dir tions and missives to Bradley in the truck are not all scripted.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya' figger' they're that far along?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I dunno'and neither do they. They're jus' happy to be out. It's a high speed Sunday drive to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sunday drive. I like that. Never heard you use that one before, Red. Sally is watching Red and listening to all of this with a troubled look on her face. Red notices...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somethin' eatin' at you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's... perhaps premature, but do you have an auxiliary roadblock plan for when they split up? Everyone stares.    No one ever questions Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you so sure they won't stay together? Sally hesitates.    Red notices...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got somethin' to say, spit it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their situation is one of accommodation. They won't be together long. Silence.   Sally continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haynes and Pugh are opposites. Haynes is a criminal's criminal -- armed robbery, mano y mano confrontation. Pugh, on the other hand, has a rap sheet littered with molestation and petty crime. They'll split sheets soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still on attack)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the hostages? They gonna' flip a coin to see who gets to keep who? Red rises and walks to the sink.      He rinses a spoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's happened before. Either way it's a dilemma they'll address soon. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why we should address it now. She looks to Red.   He refuses to return her gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have a dilemma. And neither do they. They'll keep one hostage... and get rid of one, if they haven't already.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay... which one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's a SNAFU, who's John Q. Public more likely to give a rat's ass about -- an innocent boy or a goddam bureaucrat. Red wipes the water off the spoon on his shirt and walks his office in the back. Adler, Bobby Lee and Kaiser chuck lightly at their boss's snubbing of the female upstart in their midst. Sally's face glows a bright red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red sits in his office chair, pulls out the spoon and pou Geritol from a bottle into his coffee. He doesn't even lo up when Sally enters, a stern look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to talk, Chief Garnett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you so hell-bent on embarassing me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hell-bent on one thing. You hang around long enough you'll find that out. Til' then a tough backside and a sense of humor will get you through a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a fine sense of humor, but the one thing I won't do is be your straight man so you can play hero to a bunch of morons who think you're some kind of hillbilly Sherlock Holmes.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Red sips from the mug calmly then groans, his face contor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awful. Arthur Godfrey says it keeps ya' young, but I'm not sure it's worth it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like an answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This yer' first time out of an office? She refuses to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought so.   What'd ya' expect ya' signed on for? Adler, Bobby Lee and Kaiser all watch the discussion, smi on their faces. Sally abruptly closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm what? Some dumb schoolgirl who wandered into the boy's locker room? Well you're wrong. I don't mean to boast, but I happen to be one of the two most intelligent people involved in this fiasco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't ask that.    Asked what you expected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I expected to be allowed to do the job assigned to me by the Governor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I happen to like the Governor, hunt quail together every year. But deep down he and I know that win, lose or draw this is my ship, not his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Governor as chief executive officer of this state bears ultimate responsibility for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Bullshit. Responsibility lies with the one that loses sleep; the one with the most ulcers. This mess turns bloody -- and it might -- all it's gonna cost the Governor is a few votes! Me, I'm the one that's...

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Red catches himself about to get too personal. He takes another swig of his coffee/geritol. Sally softens her sta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the one that what? But Red side-steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell ya' what. You think I'm makin' a wrong turn you speak up. Might not agree, but I'll listen. As far as stepped on toes and wounded pride, I'll buy everyone a drink when we head for home. Not until. I got more to worry about. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sound fair to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well okay then. Sally turns, about to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So who's the other one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If yer' one brain, who's the other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haynes.    He was tested in prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch drives and catches an occasional glance at Phillip sits quietly, but who, too, steals looks at his captor between swigs of RC Cola. He finishes off the bottle. Butch reaches in the sack for another, pops the top on the dashboard and hands it to Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thankyew. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you gonna' shoot me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.    Me'n you are friends.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Butch realizes that in Phillip's eyes he and Jerry were probably friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I was choosin' a runnin' buddy, I'd take you over him any day of the week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RV slides to a stop in the gravel parking lot which i full of state and local police. Red exits first, followed by the others. A LOCAL SHERIFF walks up to greet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a positive I.D.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir, with only the boy as hostage. But not five minutes ago we found something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN FROM a fingertip UP an arm and TO the face of Jerry P A clean bullethole has left him with a third eye, a blood back and an entourage of late summer flies. We hear the CLICK of a photographer's CAMERA. BOOM UP TO Red, Local Sheriff and other bystanders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Least now we know who's in charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch notices that Phillip is pretty somber as he tugs on another RC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whattaya' thinkin' about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuthin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I guess you tell me? Phillip nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thinkin' about yer mama? Phillip sits still.    That was it. Butch brings the car to a stop.    He points to the horiz Desolate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear ya', Phillip, but look around. I can't very well leave you here, can I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Impala rests in the fork of a dirt road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme' ask you somethin'.    You right or left handed? Phillip meekly holds up his right hand.    The car races forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then that's the way we'll go. You ever ridden in a time machine before? Phillip shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you have.    Whattaya' think this is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yer' lookin' at this thing bassackwards. This is a 20th Century time machine. I'm the captain and you're the navigator. Butch points forward through the dash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out there... that's the future. Butch taps on the rearview mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back there... that's the past. If life's moving too slow and you wanna' project yerself into the future you step here on the gas. See? He does so and the Impala surges forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if yer' enjoyin' the moment yer' in, well hell, just step on the brake here and you can slow it down.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Butch brings the car to a complete and dusty stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the present, Phillip.   Enjoy it while it lasts. Then he laughs uproariously and steps on the gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Impala spins out, kicking dirt in all directions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir. Time travelin' through Texas! We got to find us a Ford. My daddy always drove Fords, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Airstream sits in the parking lot of the store.   Bra and Suttle sit up front in the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley turns the knob on an intercom speaker system next to the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an intercom speaker system. You can get and give instructions to and from the rear of the vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You push the power button but if you've got the volume turned up... Bradley pushes the power button. The SYSTEM SQUAWKS LOUDL and then CREAKS TINNILY. Speakers blown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... you'll blow the speakers.   Sheeeit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red cringes, his ears still ringing from the squawk, and to stare at the front of the RV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet; to Suttle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This thing's prolly' got a warranty. You oughta' make a list of all the things that are wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red shakes his head and stands in front of the map, placi thumbtacks at crossroads indicated by the circle mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That oughta' put his pecker in a sling, huh, Red? (remembers Sally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignoring Adler)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't these be roadblocked as well? She points to several other unmarked roads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sooner or later he'll get on a main road. We don't got the manpower to roadblock every farm to market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a perfect world, Miss Gerber, we'd lock arms and thrash the bush til' he turned up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a perfect world things like this wouldn't happen in the first place. Adler hears something on his headset, turns to Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Locals are heading out.   Wanna' follow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's sit tight.    He'll turn up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Impala travels slowly along the road until it edges t stop by the entrance to a small farmhouse with a truck an car parked in a long dirt driveway. A farmer on a combine works a small field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok, Phillip, we're gonna do some  car shoppin'. You ever play cowboys   n' Injuns? See that Ford sedan? Now I want   you to sneak on over there like an Injun  and take a peek and see if the keys is in  it. Phillip hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't have to if you don't wanna... but I'd appreciate it... You bein' the new navigator and all. Phillip thinks it over then opens the door and slips out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Phillip, check for a radio, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip, still in his skivvies, legs cut up and muddied f his escape from Jerry, sneaks up to the car and quietly p into the open window. The keys dangle when his small hand touches them. Phillip closes the door, looks around and then runs pell- to the passenger window of the Impala.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got keys and a radio.   I checked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good man. Phillip holds his crotch and stamps his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we stop at a fillin' station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This here's nature, Phillip.   Pee in the ditch. Phillip scrambles to the ditch to relieve himself while B steps out of the Impala, tosses the keys into the field a walks toward the Ford.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The FARMER stops his tractor and notices Butch and Philli Phillip, despite his prior urgency, is having trouble coa relief. Butch slides into the Ford, pumps the gas pedal and turns key. The ENGINE GRUMBLES and DIES. The Farmer is walking now, slowly and then at a trot as h realizes what's happening. Phillip finally starts to pee. Butch cranks again and again but the Ford is flooded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start, you sonofabitch! The Farmer runs faster, comes closer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, that's my car! Hey!!! Butch floors the gas to clear the flood and the ENGINE fi STARTS. He throws it into reverse and peels out backwards into the road beside the ditch where Phillip continues to relieve himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in the car, Phillip! The Farmer, only 30 yards or so away, is racing toward th madder than a wet hen. Phillip tries to hurry but the RC continues to run throug him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip!   Get in the car! Phillip pulls his underwear up and races to the car. He l into the open passenger door at the same moment Butch ste the gas and the Farmer arrives and grabs onto the door as closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAR is SCREECHING down the road but the Farmer holds for dear life and auto. He claws at Phillip, who does his best to fend off flailing hands and fingers. Butch reaches under the seat for and grasps the pistol. Phillip sees what's about to happen and bites the Farmer' hand as hard as he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaaaaayyyyyy!!!! The Farmer releases his grip on the door and falls backwa summersaulting into the adjacent ditch. Butch places the gun back under the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddam, boy, how many RC's did you drink anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four. Butch shakes his head and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing's for sure. You got one helluva set of chompers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting still. Bradley tries to light a cigarette with the lighter but gets no heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Suttle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lighter don't work. Put that on the list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby Lee sits alone in the back corner of the main room the RV. He just sits and stares, occasionally smiling cynically at Sally. Adler takes the latest info off the radio while the other listen in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Highway 16 north. Four miles south of Desdemona. Got it. (to Red)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stole a vehicle. Kaiser radios up front, the ENGINE STARTS and the Airstre moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Adler)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kinda' shape's it in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ford he stole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Owner told the locals they only drove it to church, but it does have a bad emergency brake. (to Sally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd ya' know it was a Ford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He likes Fords. Adler looks at the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like you was right, Red. He's off the farm to market and onto a spur. Whattaya' wanna' do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beef up the I-20 roadblock. Adler gets more news through the headsets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red, the locals wanna' know if they're to take a clean shot if they get one? Red stares out the window for what seems like an eternity

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Adler looks quizzically at Red and pulls off the headphon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come back...? Come back Mobile One. Adler, are you there...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell 'em what I said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that a negative?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, er, yes. No means negative.     Same thing. Over. Red sees Sally peering at him over the top of her file. glances around at the other sets of eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want some half-ass Sergeant York taking pot shots with a deer rifle. Adler puts the headphones back on. Bobby Lee smirks a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the only thing to do.    He's got the child with him. Red gives her a look that says, "Don't defend me".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you figger' he'll jus' give up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well now there's a safe bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you a safe bet. The boy's in better hands now than he was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The third eye Pugh's sportin' on the way to the morgue shouts otherwise. Sally flashes Red a look back. Bobby Lee rises and moves past Red on his way to the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why not shoot to kill. Red just stares at Bobby Lee as the younger man moves slo past him to the toilet. Adler on the radio...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Red)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've forwarded the stolen vehicle license to the roadblocks. You still wanna' go to the farm? Red pulls out a package of Red Man chewing tobacco and mu over the question while he slaps a wad into his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.     I gotta' hunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got blue eyes don'tcha', Phillip? Never met a blue-eyed Phillip before. Who you named after?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and your old man get along all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeahsir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toss the ball around, play grab-ass in the yard, that sorta' thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nawsir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the hell not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't around, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he is or he ain't.       When's the last time you saw him? Phillip shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me'n you got a lot in common, Phillip. The both of us got blue eyes, we both like RC Cola and neither one of us has an old man worth a damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit defensive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Mama says he'll prolly' come back. Prolly' when I'm ten or so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... she's lyin' to ya' pure and simple. He ain't never comin' back. Disappointment registers on the boy's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys like us, Phillip, we gotta' be on our own. Seek foolish destiny, that sorta' thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ford pulls off the dusty road and into the lone pump this dilapidated petrol mirage. A BUCK TOOTH BOY, 15, in overalls steps to the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do ya' for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Phillip)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fill-er-up it is. The attendant starts to pump the gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See there! All you gotta' do is say your name and people are waiting on you hand and foot. Like a goddam king or somethin'. Phillip can't help but smile at the notion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley and Suttle lean against the parked RV, chatting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You responsible for engine maintenance on this thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah.     I'm the full time driver.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Bradley shakes his head.   "Too bad".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?   Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You notice how it keeps    wanting to slip a bit goin' into second.     Feels to me like somebody's been a little    heavy-footed with the clutch. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd take care of that if   I was you. PAN TO: an ambulance door opens and the Farmer, strapped is rolled toward it as his wife, sobbing, attends to him. Several local police scour the surrounding field, walking four feet apart, looking for what they hope they won't fi Red leans on the trunk of the Impala, chews and spits on ground. He sniffs the air. Unsavory. Adler strides up fro the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No bodies this time, thank Gawd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got the keys to this thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... naw...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me a crowbar. (to Sally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might wanna' wait in the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you.
