dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's black as night. A   CROWBAR CRANKS at the lock u the trunk blasts open like a  bottletop. A blast of light gives way to the silhouetted  faces of Red, Adler and Sal who turns and walks away in  nauseous disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well....

dialogues.speaker: OPEN TRUNK
dialogues.text: In it lies the crumpled, bent, bloody remains of Larry, t prison employee, the original hostage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... there's our bureaucrat.

dialogues.speaker: 76B RED
dialogues.text: spits a chaw, turns and walks to the RV.    Near the entr Sally is heaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to no one in particular)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's sure nice to know the boy's in good hands. Sally straightens herself, ready to bite back, but Red's face is soft. He offers a handkerchief. She takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gallows humor, Sally.    Without it we'd all be heavin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ford slides down the Main Street and into a side alle next to a Department Store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ready to get out of those skivvies and into some britches? Phillip nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well all right then. But first we gotta' come up with some A.K.A.'s, fake identities, ya' know. Names to call each other when we're around other folks. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead and think one up. Whatever name you want. Phillip is amused by the sport of it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any name I want?

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A small time Dry Goods store with a sign over the entranc proclaiming: "FRIENDLY'S - The Friendliest Store in Texas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, well-organized country dry goods store with a do or so aisles carrying everything from DDT to used boots.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A long counter at the front of the store is backed by a s office with a large glass window that gives the Manager, WILLITS, 45, bespectacled, anal-retentive, a clear view o store. A nuclear family with two kids exits the store jus Butch and Phillip enter. Butch holds the door open and sm at them. They say "thanks" but can't help but notice Phil cowering behind Butch, still clad in his underwear. He hi behind a nearby display which reads: Cast Your Vote For Friendly's Friendliest Clerk! A clerk, LUCY, 30, holding a handful of shoeboxes notices their entrance. She's schoolmarmish with a smile that loo like it's painted on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hello there and welcome to Friendly's. Looks like the little fella' needs some pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact. Shoes and new skivvies, too. He'll tell you his size. Go with the lady, Buzz. Phillip, still in somewhat of a daze, doesn't recognize h own "name".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzz! Phillip snaps to, cracks a smile at Butch and follows the to the children's section of the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzz, what a cute name.   Like a bee.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: walks past the cash register, gives the clerk behind the a wink and proceeds to an aisle which features hardware, tape, nails, etc. He stoops and grabs a shank... ... with his hands he grips the rope tight and jerks it t

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN'S AISLE
dialogues.text: Lucy is holding jeans up to Phillip's waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'd be easier if I knew your size, but we'll get it right. Phillip's eye catches something...

dialogues.speaker: HALLOWEEN COSTUME DISPLAY
dialogues.text: on a circular rack with shelves. Hanging prominantly is a Casper the Friendly Ghost costume. Above it a sign reads: "MARKED DOWN - Get the Jump on Next Year!"

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: mesmerized by the display.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: takes a roll of electrician's tape. He tears off a strip, attaches it to the back or his hand and tugs. It holds ti

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: kneeling, looking for sizes, selects a pair and turns to Phillip gone. She spins around and smiles when she sees..

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: wearing the Casper mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why look.     It's a friendly ghost.   Say 'Boo.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unconvincingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not    very scary but you'll have a whole year    to work on it if your Daddy lets you    have it. Good price, too. What'd you    go as this year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bandit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A local police car cruises slowly, spots the Ford parked the alley and comes to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop, TERRANCE, 25, who only started last month after flunked out of Texas A&M, checks the plates against a on his dash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing his find)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw... shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch, with a handful of supplies, including the rope and tape, makes his way to the register.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He's greeted there by PAULA, to whom he earlier winked. S 25, country cute, and wears a fake smile that rivals Lucy Butch reaches for and tries on a pair of sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whattaya' think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look good. He adds them to the pile of stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will that be all for you today? Butch nods and hands over the goods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You folks are about the grinninest bunch I ever seen. Paula laughs, then drops her grin, looks behind her to se Mr. Willits is watching, and whispers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old Man Willits holds a contest ever' month. The friendliest clerk gets a $20 bonus. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a ballot box at the front.

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND GLASS
dialogues.text: Mr. Willits adjusts his black and white TV and settles on local news broadcast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the hunt continues for Butch Haynes, who escaped last night from the maximum security unit over in Huntsville. Haynes, six-one, 185 pounds, with brown hair is considered armed and dangerous. He was last seen...

dialogues.speaker: CHECKOUT COUNTER
dialogues.text: Paula checks Butch's items as Lucy and Phillip emerge fro aisle and drop a pair of jeans and sneakers onto the coun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the clothes, but Buzz has his heart set on a Halloween costume for next year. It is half off.

dialogues.speaker: MR. WILLITS
dialogues.text: pays more attention to Butch as the newscast continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Haynes is believed to have an 8-year-old boy with him as hostage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each checking out the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Phillip)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll get it next time.   Go get in the car, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrance pulls his black and white to one end of Main Str and parks it across the street, blocking it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Pete, I'm all set down here.    You?

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER COP
dialogues.text: PETE, 40, probably Terrance's uncle, slides his black and white to the opposite end of the street and puts it in pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Copasetic. Let's just keep him tied up til' the state boys get here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adler takes the urgent message off the radio and turns to group...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got him penned down in Noodle, north of Abilene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paula bags the items, including the jeans.

dialogues.speaker: WILLITS
dialogues.text: staring straight at Butch.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: shakes his head at Willits -- "Don't even think about it"

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: walks toward the front door but stops short when he sees, once again, the Halloween display.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: pays Paula, then stuffs a $20 in her blouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are truly the friendliest clerk I ever met. She blushes a "thank you" as Butch makes a hasty retreat the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an afterthought)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for shopping Friendly's!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch exits the store, spots the blackandwhites, and slid into the middle of a group of old-timers moving down the sidewalk at a leisurely pace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip stands at the costume display, looks around, then grabs a Casper costume carton, stuffs it under his T-shir and walks quickly to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch slides away from the Old Timers and into the Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch checks the back seat. No Phillip, no Buzz.   He che the rear view mirror and sees...

dialogues.speaker: 90B IN REAR-VIEW MIRROR
dialogues.text: Pete, his cherry top spinning, pulls in behind Butch, blo his entrance to the main street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch throws the Ford into reverse and steps on the gas. Pete not expecxting this kind of pace, at least not from get-go, leaps into his back seat. The Ford rams into the black and white pushing it backwar into a lightpole and a truck. The TRUCK'S OWNER, carrying mulch from the feed store, watches as his truck slides toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, Pete!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip steps out the door.    He spots the crash and wat as... The Ford blasts back into the alley in a hail of dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch, driving like a maniac, turns into the back alley a steps on it. All at once he mashes on the BRAKES and come to a SQUEALING stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alley is a dead end.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Butch rips the CAR into reverse and SQUEALS all the way b to the original side alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip stands frozen, scared, not knowing what to do but keeping a look out on the street for the Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy and Paula peer from behind the counter at Phillip an the fracas taking place in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew something was wrong from the get-go. They spot Phillip standing a few feet in front of the doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, he left his little boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And look, the little rascal has... he's no better than...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got that Casper costume.   He stole it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FORD emerges from the side alley once more and SQUEAL onto Main Street.

dialogues.speaker: TERRANCE
dialogues.text: can't believe his eyes...

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: is COMING STRAIGHT FOR him, hell bent on destruction and picking up speed.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Terrance sticks his black and white in rapid reverse and down the street at 40 mph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the hell outta' there. We can't lose both vehicles!

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: is GAINING ON him -- he can actually SEE Butch's grimaced -- when suddenly it goes into a dusty fishtail, does a 18 and barrels in the OPPOSITE direction.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: antsy as hell, stuck, wondering how this whole thing is g to play out. He's suddenly aware of the peering eyes behi him. Lucy bangs on the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yells)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzz! You little shit.   Shoplifting is a crime!

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: checks his mirror, looks ahead, spots Phillip and blasts straight for the front door of the store. He SKIDS to a h and stares right at Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up to you, Buzz...

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: He's frozen for a second, his knees knocking, teeth chattering, the works. Lucy appears behind him and the glass door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Phillip)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never get away with this, little mister! Phillip dashes to the Ford and makes a swimmer's starting dive into the open passenger window.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Butch pulls his GUN and FIRES once into the glass door ab the clerk's heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GLASS DOOR and surrounding WINDOWS SHATTER into a mil pieces, sending Lucy, Paula, makeup, pantyhose, grins and into a heap on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FORD SQUEALS out down the street. Pete crawls out fro behind the seat and ducks again just as... ... the Ford sideswipes the black and white for good meas and fishtails out of town. Pete crawls over the back seat again as his radio SQUAWKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pete?... Pete?   You okay?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paula emerges from behind the counter and stares at Lucy, the ground amidst glass and mayhem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say what you want. I'm keepin' the twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two young, country boys stand by the side of the road. On FRANK, tosses an egg from hand to hand while he watches t horizon. The other, BILLY, approaches, crawling through a barb wire fence dragging something behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up.   Someone's comin'.

dialogues.speaker: ON HORIZON
dialogues.text: Sure enough, a hail of dust signals the approach of a veh a mile or so away. Billy crawls into the ditch next to Frank. We see what he dragged from the field -- a scarecrow with a floppy hat a red bandana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stick it in the road. Hurry up. Billy does so, propping the scarecrow into a sitting posi with a forked stick. Then he races back to the ditch and slides in next to Frank to divide the eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got seven eggs. I get four to throw and you get three... since it was my idea. Billy nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here they come.   Aim for windows and get ready to run. The car crests the hill, followed by another, and another a final one, all Highway Patrol, all with their lights on SIRENS WAILING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit! The cars don't even slow at the sight of the scarecrow, b ing right through it, sending hay, hat, limbs and all, fl The scarecrow, or what's left of it, lands in a ditch nex the boys. In unison they breathe a sigh of relief, look a each other, drop the eggs and hightail it for home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car is parked in a field of some sort.   Butch reache the back seat for the bag of clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, take them nasty skivvies off and put on yer' jeans. He spots Phillip's not so successful effort to hide the costume box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatya' got there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ghost suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the store?   You kyped it? Phillip nods, expecting the worst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, hell, Phillip, put it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't mad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's unnerstan' each other here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stealin's wrong, ok? But if there's somethin' you need bad and you ain't got the money, then it's okay to take a loaner on the item. It's what ya' call an exception to the rule. Phillip tears into the box, rips out the costume, looks a starts to take off his underwear then balks. Butch notice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuthin'. Butch notices Phillip's hands covering his crotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You don't wanna' get undressed, is that it? Phillip shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You embarrassed caus' I might see yer' pecker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's... puny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's puny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well hell, lemme' see. Phillip still hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.   I'll shoot ya' straight. Phillip gingerly pulls off his underwear. Butch smiles a broad grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell no, Phillip, it's good size for a boy yer' age! Phillip, remasculated, smiles and starts to put on the costume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here they come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four Highway Patrol VEHICLES from before BLAST past a 90+, sending stray dogs and roadrunners scurrying for cov CRANE    DOWN to reveal the Ford off the same roadside, b behind    a burm in a field. As soon as the patrol cars p Butch    STARTS up the ENGINE and humps it to the road an in the    opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally, deep in her files.      She looks up from the file

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby Lee who sits by himself, whittling away at a stick leering at her. Adler is at the map, holding the shortwav mike and wearing the earphones. Behind him, Red stares ou the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haynes bought tape, rope, and some clothes for the boy. Red comes to and turns to Adler. Sally smiles almost to h self. She was right -- Haynes is looking after the boy. Everyone knows it, but no one says anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One puzzler though. They say the boy could have gotten away but didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably scared to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not all. The kid stole a Halloween outfit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy Jeezus, they're a team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the pit stop in Noodle looks like he's headed for the Panhandle. Red sighs and groans. Unpleasant news but somehow he knew He moves to the back room for another shot of Geritol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Red)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's more roads than people in the Panhandle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor counties. They tend to half finish roads then start on another one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if anybody knows them backroads it's Red. Sally lifts her head, watches Red reenter the room, then stares out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, so... I'm Robert Haynes. Called Butch by everyone. I was born in Amarillo, but grew up in the French Quarter of New Orleans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto voce)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she doin', Red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I killed a man when I was eight. Silence. Nobody seems willing to play along.    Red turns from the window to Sally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd ya' kill him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shot him with a pistol. There was always one around the dance hall. That's what they called it but it was a whorehouse. We lived there. Red moves away from the discussion and stands at the fron of the Airstream, staring out the front window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd the authorities do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The victim was wanted by the locals so the whole thing got shoved under the carpet Cajun-style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They didn't even stick him in juvy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put me in school.     Three years behind but I catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like things are goin' okay' now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were.     For awhile.   When I'm twelve mom dies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delilah Jane Haynes hung herself in the bathroom of the brothel. Could have saved herself the trouble. Post-mortem check uncovered last stage syphilis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's yer' father? Red's face tells us he's listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody knows where he is now. Ditched when I was six. He was a small-time felon. Popped up again after Mom died -- he'd just been paroled. Moved us back to Amarillo. A year later I'm in trouble again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?     Kill somebody else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Took a joyride in a Ford coupe that I just couldn't resist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, that's no big deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge gave me four years in Gatesville, toughest juvy farm in Texas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where the son-of-a-bitch learned to be a criminal. Seen that before, ain't we, Red? Red doesn't answer.     He seems in a faraway place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smart ass)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Butch, why don't you tell us where yer' goin', save us the trouble o' huntin' you down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where I'm going isn't as important as 'Why am I going there?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tired of the game)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. 'Caus' I'm runnin' and they're chasin' and I'd jus' as soon go north as south as east as west. It's a fun lil' parlor game, lady, but right now Butch Haynes don't have the slightest idea where he's headed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip, now fully-attired in his Casper outfit and mask, looking at a folded map while Butch drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An inch is 24 miles. Hold yer' pointin' finger along the line of the road. You got three lines on your finger, don'tcha'? Each one's an inch. So how many inches to Childress? Phillip holds one finger to the map, then another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One, two... six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yer' a helluva' navigator, Phillip. A lot smarter than Jerry. But I guess that's not sayin' a lot. Something catches Phillip's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lookie there!

dialogues.speaker: TRUCK AND AIRSTREAM
dialogues.text: coming TOWARD them on the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley, driving, tinkers with a broken windowshade. Suttle yawns, comes to, notices the broken windowshade an gives Bradley a look. Bradley, caught, just smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited, too)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen one of them in a magazine. It's called a motor home. They're new. Kinda' like a house on wheels. Butch HONKS the HORN TWICE and waits for a retort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley smiles, looks to Suttle, who nods an "okay."    J sits on the HORN for TWO solid BLASTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip laughs and waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley and Suttle wave back.

dialogues.speaker: SALLY
dialogues.text: staring out the window.    She looks at the passing Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch is hard to make out, but there's no mistaking the C outfit Phillip wears with pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said the boy stole a Halloween costume... What character?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe it was Casper... Casper the friendly ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was them.   They just passed us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn this thing around! Adler jumps on the radio to the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn it around! That was them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Airstream slows to a grind, pulls off the narrow shou and begins to make a wide U-turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll never make it. Stop! It's a close fit but the Airstream just survives a brush a burm. The TRUCK PEELS away with Airstream in tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch checks his rear-view mirror and gets a puzzled look his face.

dialogues.speaker: IN REAR-VIEW MIRROR
dialogues.text: The Airstream barreling fast behind -- catching up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley presses the pedal to the floor. The ENGINE STRAIN Suttle nervously sneaks a peek at the speedometer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's... it's not safe to go over 65 with this much load! The speedometer reaches 80.   The ENGINE SCREAMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole thing is shaking, twisting, bumping.    All abo and keep their balance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Adler)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him to pull up next to 'em! Bobby Lee opens a window and leans out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Bobby Lee leans out the window of the Airstream some 5 yards back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip turns around backward in the seat to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're goin' fast!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip, you get in the back seat and lie down on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I don't know. 'Caus' I said so!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suttle is scared to death while Bradley is loving every minute. The ENGINE starts to STEAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yer burnin' up the engine! But Bradley pays no heed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby Lee unholsters his pistol and leans back out the window. Red spots him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holster that firearm and get yer ass back inside! Bobby Lee thinks it over, shakes his head in disgust and holsters his piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch spots an opening and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on, Phillip!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ford makes a sharp veer off the road into a flat scru brush field. The car spins out a bit when it hits the dir sending forth a dust devil, then it regains its traction blasts ahead through the dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley spots the maneuver and starts to follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck, in an attempt to enter the field, misses the f spot, hits a burm with its front right tire and flies int the air.

dialogues.speaker: 111J CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The trailer hitch snaps as does the safety chain. The truck lands hard and continues pell-mell through the field. The AIRSTREAM, sans truck, BLASTS forward along the road at 50+ m.p.h.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bouncing like hell. Sally holds on for dear life, then glances out the window and almost jumps out of her seat w she sees...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck, 100 or so yards away, blasting through the fie toward the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red spots the same but before he can cuss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Airstream veers off the road and into the rocky field Trees, scrub brush and boulders are no deterrent for the sleek silverfish which seems to be moving even faster tha before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steam, smoke pouring from the engine. Suttle, covering hi eyes, sneaks a peek behind and screams when he sees no Airstream behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhhh!!    They're gone!!! Bradley looks in the rear-view mirror, turns around and screams, too. Without visual guidance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TRUCK BLASTS into a mesquite tree, runs halfway up the tree, then dies a horrible death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an anti-gravity room what with the files, coffee, ma and bodies flying around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Airstream, now losing a bit of steam, hits a burm, al topples and comes to a precarious stop in a dried-up wate hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adler, still wearing the headphones, rises first and goes the radio to answer an incoming call. Red groans. Sally crawls to her feet and offers Red a hel hand, which he accepts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... Red?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wanna know if the boy looked okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was laughing and waving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell 'em that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large group of very serious advisors sit and stand in a circle around the Governor's desk. Across from GOVERNOR CONNALLY sits a nervous, near tears GLADYS PERRY. An AIDE on the telephone, turns to the Governor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say the boy looked A-okay. Governor Connally nods, sighs, and reaches hand across th desk and touches Gladys's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be fine, Mrs. Perry. This whole nightmare will be over and done with very soon and you'll be home with your boy. I promise. Gladys, distraught, nods. Governor Connally discreetly no to a photographer in the group while keeping his hand on Gladys's shoulder. A CAMERA'S FLASH causes everyone to bl in reaction. The Governor shakes it off and continues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to know that I personally okayed the use of a brand-new high-tech mobile home from which to conduct the manhunt. It's an amazingly futuristic piece of law enforcement equipment. Another FLASH.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 115

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Airstream, the amazingly futuristic piece of law enforcement equipment sits beat to hell and leaning to on side in the dry pond bed. All the tires are flat and dent and bruises abound. The door tries to open but is stuck. Red applies a boot to it and the whole thing comes off it hinges and flies to the ground. Red exits. He groans and shakes his head when he spots... Bradley and Suttle limping toward him across the field. Red sighs and starts slowly walking in the direction Butc and Phillip headed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally, her hair a bird's nest, does her best to collect h files before she sits down, takes a deep breath and glanc out the window at Red in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: RED
dialogues.text: Standing in the middle of the field, staring at the horiz He sticks a chaw in his mouth without diverting or blinki his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: Staring at the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch sits on the hood of the Ford, which is stopped on a asphalt road which, a few feet farther, turns into dirt a a few feet farther a dirt clod field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Started this road 20 years ago and it still ain't finished. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Appears to me we got a decision to make. Phillip, aka Casper, exits the car and, imitating Butch, against the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's up to you, Phillip. We can backtrack to the highway or we can try it on foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where we goin'? Butch reaches in his back pocket and pulls out a folded postcard. He hands it over to Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: CARD
dialogues.text: It's at least 20 years old, crumpled. It unfolds to revea beautiful green valley with a snow capped mountain behind

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Alaska, Phillip. Last of the wild frontier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw. Just got the one postcard. But anyhoo, back to our present dilemma. You feel like a hike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't be more'n, oh, say, fifteen hundred miles. Phillip seems a tad apprehensive about the prospect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yer' prolly' right. Go give our supplies a check. Phillip returns to the car and emerges with the paper bag full of soda, candy and jerky. Butch surveys the countrys

dialogues.speaker: PAN COUNTRYSIDE
dialogues.text: Typical midwest Texas; flat, dusty, barren.     A mile or away sits a home -- a small ranchhouse.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Phillip returns with the bag and pores through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A soda... some gum... half a Moon Pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rations for one at best.    Come on. Butch strides straight into the rocky field. Phillip lingers a moment, then sticks the half eaten moon pie in his mouth and follows, hurrying to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: thru 122

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suttle limps around the broken-down silver junker, his ha covering what his eyes can't bear to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now yer sure that gooseneck had a safety chain? Suttle turns and glares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red walks slowly toward the slumping Airstream. A PHONE RINGS from inside, then STOPS. Adler sticks his head out the door and calls to Red...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Governor's hot line, Red. Governor insists that he have the mobile home back for the parade tomorrow. Red just stares at Adler, then sighs, removes his hat and scratches his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (isn't it obvious?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell 'em to come and get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch continues his hell-bent brisk pace in the field of clods. It's all Phillip can do to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where we goin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're goin' trick r' treatin', Phillip. Phillip stops dead in his tracks. Butch, sensing that the is no longer following, stops, spins and faces Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ain't allowed to trick r' treat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mama don't allow it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trick r' treatin'? Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against our religion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against yer' religion.     What kind of foolishness is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jehovah Witness. Butch picks up a dirt clod and hurls it as far as he can. sighs and turns to Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I'm askin' you, Phillip. I ain't askin' yer' mother and I ain't askin' Jehovah. Do you wanna' go trick r' treatin' or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch and Phillip cross the dirt yard and make their way the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ok, Phillip, all ya' gotta' do is knock on the door and when they open it you say 'trick or treat.' Got it? They arrive at the door.   Butch nods at Phillip who RING BUZZER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait til' they come. A FARM WIFE, 65 or so, like something from a Grant Wood, smiling, opens the door and looks out on the pair through screen door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trick r' treat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ain't you the cutest lil' ghost I ever did see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it again, Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trick r' treat, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, seein' that Halloween was yesterday, I guess you'll have to trick me. You missed the caramel popcorn balls I made up special. Butch smiles, pulls up his shirt and exposes the revolver stuck in his pants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tune changed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait right here. Butch smiles and pats Phillip on the shoulder.    His eye drawn to...

dialogues.speaker: TELEPHONE WIRE
dialogues.text: which enters the house near the door. We PAN WITH the telephone line FROM the house TO a nearby pole.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The Woman returns with an armload of anything she could f in the kitchen. Phillip gratefully opens his sack and wat as the Woman drops in a loaf of bread, a jar of mustard, candies, jams, butter and anything else she could find. Empty-handed she reaches inside the door, opens her purse dumps her money -- a couple of dollars and lots of change the bag. Phillip smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thankyew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip, sack in hand, waves goodbye to the frightened ol Woman, who shuts her door and locks it. Butch and Phillip make their way back across the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never underestimate the kindness of the common man, Phillip. Butch reaches up and grabs the phone line, yanks it loose tosses it aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Airstream is fast becoming a pig sty. Coke bottles, coffee spills, overfull ashtrays, etc. are everywhere. Ad holds the mike and stares at the thumbtacked map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mike)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spur 208 northbound. And 83 at Aspermont coming and going. (to Red)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Adler moves to set down the mike and topples a cup of cof It spills on the floor. Suttle grabs a towel to wipe it u but realizing the futility of keeping the Airstream clean simply throws it aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch drives while Phillip digs through the sack and come up with a jar of mustard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure there's no meat in there? Spam maybe, Vienna sausages, anything like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nawsir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I bet you can make us some mustard sandwiches, can't ya'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeahsir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well go to it. Phillip breaks out the loaf of bread and lays out four slices on the dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many as you want. Phillip   lays out six more slices. The dashboard is now covered   with bread. Phillip pulls out the mustard but h knife.    Butch pulls out a stick of gum and hands it to Phillip   to spread with. As they drive  along they pass a large, happy family (Mom girl 5, boy 7)  picnicking in the dip of a long hill alon the highway.   From the look of their brand-new loaded do station wagon  they are on vacation.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: Mesmerized by the family.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: Ditto.    He pulls his eyes back to the road, notices som

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch brings the car to a stop near the crest of the hill sets the emergency brake, grabs the first completed musta sandwich and gets out, leaving the Impala running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be right back. Don't be stingy with that mustard now. Phillip nods and continues piling the yellow goop on each the slices of bread.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: walks ahead to the crest of the hill, the tallest hill in county. He takes in the 360 degree view. His eyes settle on...

dialogues.speaker: LINE OF CARS
dialogues.text: IDLING as they wait their turn to pass a roadblock at the bottom of the hill.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: spreading even more mustard. Every so often he sneaks a p back at the picnicing family.

dialogues.speaker: EMERGENCY BRAKE
dialogues.text: slips a little, then gives all at once.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: starts to roll backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whooaaa!   Butch!    Butch!!!

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: turns and sees the Ford rolling backwards, picking up ste back down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Step on the brake! Put your foot on the brake! The middle one!!

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: panicked, slides over and grabs the wheel. Of course, he too short to press on the brake and when he bends down...

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: swerves off the road and onto the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY
dialogues.text: headed by BOB, 35, their Ward Cleaverish father, looks up see...

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: barrelling backwards toward them, swerving to and fro and followed by Butch shouting instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody, run!    Quick!

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: makes a beeline for the station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget the car, Bob!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you crazy.    It's only got a 1000 miles on it! He jumps in the Driver's seat of the WAGON and franticall REVS it just as...

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: gains control of the wheel and steers the rapidly reversi Ford around the Wagon.

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: continues backwards to the bottom of the hill, but it has enough steam built up to head backwards up the other incl of the previous hill.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: comes to a heaving halt next to Bob, who is near heart at himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad brakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was close. Bob gets out of the station wagon and stands next to Butc They watch for the Ford for a second, see that it's losin momentum and smile at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob Fielder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edgar Poe.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: breathes a sigh of relief as the Ford loses momentum and to a stop. But then, of course, ...

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: like any car on a roller coaster, starts to move downhill slowly at first, but then picking up speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had me scared silly.      I've only had her two months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a beaut, all right. Say,      Bob, what with my brake problem and all,     I sure would appreciate a lift. Me'n my boy      live about five miles up the road here. I      can pick up the car tomorrow. They notice the Ford coming back down the hill and squint see...

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: coming straight for them, gaining speed, with Casper the friendly ghost behind the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH AND BOB
dialogues.text: chuck the small.    Bob looks for a place to hide.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: Screaming at the top of his lungs.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: Staring straight ahead at Phillip. Butch doesn't even flinch, standing his ground in the mid of the road, staring straight into Phillip's oncoming fac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brake, Phillip! Step on the brake! Hard!

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: totally freaked, jumps down on the floorboard and pushes both hands on the brake. SQUEALING TIRES bring...

dialogues.speaker: FORD
dialogues.text: to a SKIDDING halt inches from Butch's kneecaps.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: smiles at Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helluva job, Phillip! Never had a doubt.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: Smiling back.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: crawls down from the luggage rack on top of his wagon and smiles a sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Highway Patrol officers check licenses and peek into at the checkpoint. In the b.g. we see the red station wag in line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's   full to the brim with the Family Bob plus two, But and   Phillip, who ride in the back with Bob's son. As th car   approaches the roadblock Butch grabs a blanket, rec and   hides behind a stuffed animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry for the inconvenience, Edgar. The kids like the back down like that so they can play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No trouble at all, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob brings his precious car to a gingerly stop.    He pul his license, shows it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the roadblock, Officer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Escaped convict, sir. Just a precaution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bradley examines the gooseneck hitch. Bobby Lee sits on a nearby rock, still whittling at his stick. It's starting resemble something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As in the old Westerns, it's quiet, too quiet. The      i the RV is pretty much trashed now -- the product of     m working in close contact. Sally stares at a file.       T silence is broken as Red spits tobacco juice into an Coke bottle. Sally peruses a file.

dialogues.speaker: FILE
dialogues.text: It's Butch's again. She's reading an addendum page with JUVENILE COURT RECORD stamped at the top. A photo of 14-y old Butch is stapled in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Sally finds something very interesting.    She looks up a He returns her stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bobby Lee finishes his whittling, blows away shavings, smiles at his creation, sets it on the rock, gets up and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: HIS CREATION
dialogues.text: A four inch long wooden replica of a high caliber shell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adler is getting something on the shortwave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Red)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've got two Highway Patrol cars they can give to us now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell 'em stand by. We got the     best seat in the house right here. Have     the southern roadblocks call in the    dogs and move north. Check every road,     every farm from San Angelo to Sweetwater.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Adler surveys the map and sticks in a few more thumbtacks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows he's hemmed in. I predict we'll have him singing a different tune by nightfall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The red station wagon creeps along the highway to the whistled strains of "Old MacDonald had a Farm."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch, truly "singing a different tune," whistles "Old MacDonald." Bob joins in and soon the whole damn Family B is whistling the tune. Bob's daughter PATSY, 5, red hair, freckles, starts jumpi up and down on the back seat, singing and spilling her dr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're spilling!     You're spilling! Bob and his Wife immediately turn around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patsy!    Look at what you're doing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahhh noooo! Bob's wife grabs Patsy by the arm and shakes her. Butch c tinues to whistle softly, almost eerily, but he's watchin closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at what you did! It's all over the seat of your father's new car! The little girl    starts to cry while Bob grabs at tissu feverishly and    hands them to his Wife who, leaning ove seat is wiping    hard at the stain. She grabs her daught arm and shakes    her, staring into her face. Butch, directly behind the little girl, watches closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is wrong with you?! I told you twice not to jump up and down! Didn't I!! Patsy bawls harder than ever. Bob's Wife finishes wiping reseats herself in the front seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn that kid! The little girl is crying harder than ever now. Bob reach back over the seat and tries to touch his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, sweetie. Daddy's not mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So much for the new car smell. The little girl muffles her tears. Butch smiles sincerely then looks to the passing landscap

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This will do fine right here, Bob.   But I do have one more favor to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire Family Bob is standing along the roadside, the luggage and belongings by their side. The looks on their faces say it all -- Stranded. Butch hands over the stuffed animal to Patsy, pats Bob Jr the head and sticks out his hand to Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a loaner, Bob. Not to worry.    You'll get her back. Bob reluctantly shakes Butch's hand in an attempt to impr upon Butch his most important concern of all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, it's new. Hold it under 45... at least for the next 500 miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I will, Bob. Butch gives a snappy salute and is off to the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch STARTS the CAR and he and Phillip slowly pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wave, Phillip. Phillip does so.   Bob's kids wave back.   Phillip starts giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, but Bob did the right thing. What if he'd put up a fight? I mighta' had to shoot him, and where would that family be then? Naw, Bob's a fine family man and that's about the best thing a fella' can hope to be. Butch floors the wagon and the CAR SCREECHES rubber on th highway.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: cringes as he watches his pride and joy rocket toward the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Highway Patrol continues to monitor cars one by one. of the Officers sees something and nudges his partner to at...

dialogues.speaker: FAMILY BOB
dialogues.text: cresting the hill carrying their hats in their hands alon with their luggage and coolers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adler drops his headphones and turns to Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He got through!    At Aspermont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coerced a motorist. Red sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well goddam, shout at Amarillo. Tell 'em we got a notion he's headed their way. Adler gets right to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Truth is I wish he'd cross the border so we could turn this over to the feds. Nobody in the room expected to hear this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got work to do back home. Red rises and stretches, walks to the open door and stare at the late afternoon light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hungry.   This thing got any food?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh... Adler jumps up and goes to the frig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got T-bones in the frig, Red!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, uh, those were stocked for the Governor. I don't think that he would approve of... Adler finds a plastic bag in the freezer and inspects it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And look, Red!     Tater Tots!   Those kind you like! Red turns and looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch fiddles with the RADIO. He settles on a Spanish station playing a BALLAD and ADJUSTS the VOLUME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't find a Coonass Waltz to save my ass. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Phillip, that stuff you told me 'bout not trick r' treatin' causa' Jehovah... Was you pullin' my leg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nawsir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else ain't you suppose' to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't get Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yer' shittin' me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nawsir.   No birthdays, nor parties, neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't never been to a carnival neither, have ya'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nawsir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cotton candy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen that once.     It's red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never ate none though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roller coasters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Phillip, you have a goddammed red, white and blue American right to eat cotton candy and ride roller coasters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do?

dialogues.speaker: MOUTH
dialogues.text: screaming.   PULL BACK to reveal...

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: still screaming in glee, the wind blowing his crew-cut straight up into the air. PULL BACK FARTHER to reveal that Phillip is firmly tied t the luggage rack of the station wagon, which is rocketing across the winding plains of West Texas. BOOM DOWN to reveal Butch, having almost as much fun as Phillip, hooping and hollering as he steps on the gas and weaves to and fro trying his damndest to hit every bump.

dialogues.speaker: DUSK
dialogues.text: A Nehi Orange sun pours itself into the Grape-Ade Davis Mountains. PAN ALONG the horizon PAST nothing but open sp ... Then a red neon sign, small and broken down, like the grill diner it advertises. The stolen station wagon sits alone beside the pressed di parking lot of Dottie's Cafe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A skinny, small town WAITRESS checks her face in a bathro mirror. She applies too much lipstick and pinches her che before exiting. We FOLLOW as she exits the kitchen bathro door, grabs two already prepared hamburger platter specia from beside the grill and moves through a swinging door i the diner. A counter, three booths, grease everywhere... She sets the two plates in front of Butch and Phillip at booth. Butch digs in but Phillip holds for a beat. Butch notices and stops chewing while Phillip says "grace".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet as a mouse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thankyew, Father, for yer' 'boundiful' nature and goodness. Butch and the Waitress/cook share a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen.  Now dig in, Buzz. (to Waitress)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call him that caus' he eats like a buzzard. If it's dead he'll swoop and chow.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She leans down to the table and flirts with her overdone

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You Dottie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eileen. Dottie died. Her son runs the place but... he ain't never here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves at four. Not much traffic after lunch. She brazenly stares a hole through Butch as she lifts a s of pickle off his plate, places it in her mouth and slowl chews. Phillip, mouth full, takes note of the confusing spectacl Eileen turns to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you need me, I'll be right over here. She slowly sashays away to behind the counter. Butch watches her every step. Phillip chews and watches Butch's eyes. Butch turns his head and catches Phillip watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat yer' food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SIRLOIN STEAK hits a grill beside a Tater Tot shiskabob SIZZLES to beat the band. A homemade barbecue pit, built from nearby abundant rocks sits square in the middle of the highway with red flares up just in case a car did come by. Red smiles and shakes a liberal dose of Lea and Perrins o the flesh. He's obviously a veteran of many back yard B-B and this is definitely one. We see Sally THROUGH the window. She's inside, still goin over her files. She gets up and walks into the back room look for something.

dialogues.speaker: BOBBY LEE
dialogues.text: sitting outside, rises and slides into the Airstream whil

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Red continues to cook with Adler and Bradley looking on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally turns on a nightlight and looks at herself in the mirror. She splashes a little water on her face and is startled when ... Bobby Lee slides in behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think yer' pretty smart now don'tcha'? She doesn't back down, instead looking him straight in th eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well yer' not smart but you are pretty. Sally stares right at Bobby Lee then moves for the door. shifts his position and blocks her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Bobby Lee smiles a crooked-tooth grin, refusing to move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work and pleasure should naturally go together don't you think? Take me, I enjoy my work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could give a shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a mouth, don't ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you take your steak, Sally? Bobby Lee and Sally both look up to see Red standing in t doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (relieved)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh.. rare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman after my own heart. She takes this opportunity to slide between Red and Bobby on her way into the main room. As she goes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just wipe its ass, herd it through and you can cut off a hunk. How'd that be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe medium-rare. Bobby Lee and Red are left standing face to face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't give a damn who you work for. You're here for one reason and one reason only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else, Chief?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   Yer' in my office. The hot line PHONE RINGS... Bobby Lee flinches first and moves back into the main roo Red follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the Governor's line, Red! Red calmly walks past Sally who smiles a "thanks". He giv her a one finger to the hat salute, walks to the phone, reaches down and yanks out the cord. The RINGING STOPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nuthin' as impolite as callin' at the dinner hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip, at the booth, plays with the parsley on his empt plate, which sits across from Butch's barely touched one. boy looks over his shoulder and sneaks a peek at Butch, w sits at a barstool watching Eileen work behind the counte

dialogues.speaker: AT COUNTER
dialogues.text: Butch leans over and whispers something sexy into Eileen' ear. She giggles and licks her lips. Butch feels eyes on his back and looks at Phillip, who immediately turns away from them. When Butch returns his attention to Eileen she's moved a few feet away and is refilling ketchup bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzz, go ahead and chew on mine if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thankyew. Eileen slides back down toward Butch. She makes refilling condiment bottles the sexiest pasttime since the hula hoo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very polite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I try hard but, ya' know, since his mama died...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- My mama's not dead! Butch, a tad annoyed, turns to Phillip and gives him a lo Once again, when he turns back, Eileen has moved. She's flirting with Butch, moving, bending, wiping her ha on her hips. His eyes are focused on her every squirm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay now, Buzz, you go on out in the parking lot and chunk some rocks or something.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Phillip reluctantly slides down off the stool and slowly out the door. His eyes stay on Butch and Eileen, barely concealing confusion mixed with a hint of jealousy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So is she dead or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (covering badly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well his biological mother is alive. Gave him up for adoption to me and my wife. My dead wife, that is. She is, was Phil, er Buzz's stepmother, so she's his mom, was his mom, stepmom, but... she's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry. But she's not.     In fact it seems to have turned her on more. She puts her hand behind Butch's neck and slowly pulls hi close for gentle kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip tosses a rock then turns to the diner. They're go Phillip drops his handful of rocks and walks to the front window of the diner.

dialogues.speaker: DINER
dialogues.text: It is empty. He sees that the kitchen swinging door is st swinging on its hinges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A one room addition office built onto    the kitchen. It desk against one wall, a few chairs, a    fan -- pretty s Two large windows throw light from the    outside neon si the room. A large lamp provides harsh     light. Eileen leads Butch by the hand into the room, closing the behind them. At once they are all over each other. Butch lifts her up onto the desk and starts to kiss her face an neck. Then, in an instant, he flips her over, pulls the ribbon from her hair and unzips the back of her waitress outfit to the waist. He kisses her neck, her back and suddenly, passionately, he flips up her skirt and begins kissing her voluptuous backside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip, a bit scared, moves around the side of the front the diner and sees something.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH WINDOW
dialogues.text: In profile Butch continues to kiss Eileen's buttocks. moans in ecstasy.

dialogues.speaker: 151C BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Phillip, like a pacifist at a prizefight, doesn't want to watch but can't not watch. He moves down the wall to a window positioned right at the desk. When he stops he's r in front of the window, separated from Butch and Eileen b only a foot of air and a thin plate of glass.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH AND EILEEN
dialogues.text: Kissing, writhing, but FROM this ANGLE  all he can really is a mane of hair swinging to and fro.   Butch is out of but it's obvious that his lips continue  to caress Eileen backside. She cranes her neck, arching   it like a swan, moaning like a wildebeast and then... She stops and stares STRAIGHT AHEAD. Butch continues to k but only for a beat, sensing the locomotive he's on has stopped at an unscheduled station. He slides his face fro around her rear, a la Kilroy, and he stares, too. Except their continuing heavy breathing they could be modern art statues staring STRAIGHT AHEAD AT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip's nose is pressed to the glass.   In fact if he p any harder there wouldn't be any glass.

dialogues.speaker: 152B BUTCH AND EILEEN
dialogues.text: hold their pose for a second until...

dialogues.speaker: 152C PHILLIP
dialogues.text: comes back to real time and bolts away into the darkness the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nosy little feller'.

dialogues.speaker: 152D BUTCH
dialogues.text: races to the side window and watches as Phillip runs into parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phillip!...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a last try)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I keep a cot in the back. But Butch, still at the window, just keeps breathing.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Nothing but stars swimming in black West Texas crude.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: stands right next to the SPUTTERING NEON SIGN, staring straight up, the neon light splashing his face in a grote pink light.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: In the b.g., over his shoulder, the cafe door opens, CLAN a string of BELLS as Butch hastily exits and walks past Phillip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. Butch drives away libidinous desires, Phillip si quietly, staring straight ahead, now and again stealing a at Butch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mad at me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. More silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kissed her, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (much regret)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jus' barely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caus' it feels good. Ain't you ever seen your mama kiss a man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kissed her backside, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's, well, uh, it's kinda' hard to explain. I know how it musta' looked. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I don't know how it looked.... As Butch's voice trails off silence overtakes the car. Af a few seconds Butch seems happy not to have to answer any more questions. Phillip fidgits with the door handle. Several more seconds pass, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lady that cooked the hamburgers? Butch ponders this, then a grin slides across his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Phillip, I love her. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kissed her butt didn't I? And they both start to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The station wagon pulls off the main dirt road and onto a smaller, private road. After 150 yards or so, it leaves t graded dirt and, shocks bouncing, crosses into a plowed f and comes to a dusty stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna' drive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jus' kiddin', Buzz. I'm just gonna' stop here for awhile and catch 40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch KILLS the ENGINE but keeps the RADIO MUSIC on low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things go our way we'll be in Alaska in four or five days. Get the jump on winter. Phillip looks a little sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna' go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you wanted to go home so bad, why didn't you stay at that store today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caus'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caus' why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Caus' I stole. They'd put me in jail. Prolly' go to hell. Butch chuckles at the notion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Same difference.    We'll get you home soon. I swear, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Phillip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done proved that ain'tcha'? There's lots and lots of stuff you can do, Phillip. (gets an idea)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reach in that glovebox there. See if Bob's got a notepad or something. Phillip extracts a small ringed memo pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good old Bob. Can you write?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can print.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good enough. Now I want you to make a list of everything you ever wanted to do but wasn't allowed to. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like... cotton candy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cotton candy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell I don't know. It's yer' list. Butch settles in for a catnap.      Just as his eyes clos

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Butch?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only the dome light and the LOW MUSIC bring attention to the car sitting lonely in the middle of the massive field

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya' spell 'rocketship?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The aftermath of a full scale Texas Bar-B-Q: plates full gristle and bone, cigarettes burning in ashtrays and swir ing in half-drunk bottles of Coke and mugs of coffee, men groaning and picking their teeth with toothpicks. Bradley, Adler and Suttle are dead-ass asleep and snoring Bobby Lee, too mean to sleep, sits by himself cleaning hi fingernails with a pocket knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red leans against the Airstream and sips coffee from his thermos. Sally walks up, sipping from a mug, and leans against the bumper. Red doesn't even turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Figger to give 'em another hour of shuteye, then grab the patrol cars and head for the Panhandle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring back any memories?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too many. Red turns to her.    They both know he's divulged somethi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got a file on me, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the 60's, Red. They've got a file on everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just caus' it's written down don't make it true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You worked as County Sheriff in Amarillo and Austin before you became a Ranger. Right so far? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and it says your name's Cecil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, that's definitely the worst of it. Red uncorks his thermos and refills Sally's mug.    She t a sip and almost chokes on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strong... but good. So Cecil... Red gives her a strong look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red. What do you do when you're not at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The file don't tell ya' that, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a ranch I never visit, nieces I hardly know, a tackle box full of dry lures and a dog that figures he's the owner and I'm the pet.  Could have a point, he's there more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A confirmed bachelor. Any regrets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liked to have wet those lures. Maybe a new dog. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get into... whatever the hell it is you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father's defense lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That explains your mouth. Sally smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instead of Home Ec, I studied Criminology. When I graduated, my father, with the Governor's help, they, he and my dad... I created a position for myself with the prison system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's yer' husband think about all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't own one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yer' not careful you'll wind up jus' like me. Old, tired, with nobody around to love ya'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's crazy ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goin' without sleep chasin' after a three time loser and Casper the Friendly Ghost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep?    That's what retirement's for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bite your tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna' know what's really crazy? Hayne's juvenile court record lists you as Amicus Curiae. Silence save the CRICKETS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friend of the court. Evidence given by a non-party with the intention of swaying the judge one way or the other. They're usually in written form, but there's no copy attached. Red doesn't flinch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, then at least tell me why Haynes got four years for a joyride? What about probation? The boy had a home, a father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your file say about him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That he was a petty thief who did a little time, got out and stayed pretty clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are murderers I'd trust with my mother and petty thieves I wouldn't turn my back on. Your precious files are wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hayne's old man was a career criminal with a soft spot for whores. One way or the other he beat the hell outta' every person he ever crossed, screwed or fathered. Judge sends junior home with the old man and you can bet your last dollar that within a year he'll have a rap sheet as long as yer arm. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know kids who did Gatesville, made it through, shaped up. Hell, one's even a priest. Sally realizes she's opened an old wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, I don't understand from the file why...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- This job ain't about files and books and second guessin'. Ya get one shot and ya call 'em like you see 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a bit confused... Red tosses out the rest of his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Texas the bottom line is who ya' know and what they owe ya. That's how I do my job and how you got yours. He turns to walk inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a bit ticked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you trying to say? Red stops, faces Sally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bought the judge a T-bone and told him to send the boy up. Told him it was the right thing to do. He went along right down the line. Red disappears. Sally just stares after him, her face once again soft.

dialogues.speaker: MEMO PAD
dialogues.text: resting on Phillip's lap.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: His fingers release it as he drifts to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: PHILLIP
dialogues.text: asleep, the way a child sleeps.    Soundly.

dialogues.speaker: BUTCH
dialogues.text: also asleep, but only his body -- his mind works over- time...

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: (NOTE: the entire dream is a series of snapshots to a strong Coonass beat) A)   A baby snapshot of Butch.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: B)   A Haynes family photo -- a grizzled father standing behind a mother seated holding a baby. They stand in front of a small, white framed house. C)   Extreme closeup -- The baby in the snapshot - Butch. D)   Snapshot of a young Butch, age 6, with his father an another adult male, who are both holding deer rifles with one hand and with the other the antlers and head of a dead deer. E)   Extreme closeup -- Butch's father from the same phot F)   Snapshot of Butch, 8, with his mother but no father. G)   An establishing snapshot of a nightclub in New Orlea The gaudy sign above the joint reads: CLUB - DANCE HALL. H)   A snapshot of Butch's mother dressed in a somewhat sleazy Latino outfit. She's surrounded by 3 or 4 lounge lizard types, whose hands are all placed on parts of her body. She has a drunken sneer on her face. I)   Snapshot of Butch, 8, being taught to dance in the c by his mother. He looks awkwardly into the camera. J)   Snapshot of Butch, 8, sitting on the bar of the club surrounded by a motley group of sleazy "dime dancers". K)   Another snapshot of Butch being taught to dance by h drunken mother. (NOTE: A heavy MACHINE GROWL should START LOW and INCREAS IN VOLUME through the remainder of these fast-paced serie of cuts.)
